articles.headline: A Big Loss at Merrill Stirs Unease
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch’s Friday announcement that it would write down $5 billion primarily in its fixed-income sector raised questions about the company’s discipline.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch’s Friday announcement that it would write down $5 billion primarily in its fixed-income sector raised questions about the company’s discipline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since becoming chief executive of Merrill Lynch in 2002, E. Stanley O’Neal has been credited with making the investment bank leaner and more disciplined.

articles.headline: G.M. Pact Calls for a Push for Health Care Reform
articles.snippet: G.M. has agreed to spend up to $15 million over the next few years to establish an institute to develop strategies for national health care reform.
articles.abstract: G.M. has agreed to spend up to $15 million over the next few years to establish an institute to develop strategies for national health care reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Oct. 5 — For years, General Motors has said it supports the United Automobile Workers union in its push for change in the nation’s health care system. Now the U.A.W. has persuaded G.M. to put its money where its mouth is.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Mary M. Chapman

articles.headline: Of Tiers, Football and Dollars
articles.snippet: Sports content is expensive and valuable, but some cable TV companies are starting to think the leagues may have exaggerated their worth.
articles.abstract: Sports content is expensive and valuable, but some cable TV companies are starting to think the leagues may have exaggerated their worth.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, James E. Delany, the commissioner of the Big Ten conference, went to a meeting with executives from Disney, which owns both the ABC television network and the various ESPN cable channels. The Big Ten and Disney were past the halfway point of a 10-year agreement, due to expire in 2007, that paid the Big Ten around $1 billion to televise its best football games each season. The meeting was the first negotiation toward a new deal.

articles.headline: After Extensive Beef Recall, Topps Goes Out of Business
articles.snippet: Topps Meat Company could not recover after pulling back more than 21.7 million pounds of ground beef products in one of the largest meat recalls in recent years.
articles.abstract: Topps Meat Company could not recover after pulling back more than 21.7 million pounds of ground beef products in one of the largest meat recalls in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Topps Meat Company, one of the country’s largest manufacturers of frozen hamburgers, said yesterday that it was going out of business a week after it pulled back more than 21.7 million pounds of ground beef products in one of the largest meat recalls in recent years.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: $6 Million for the Co-op, Then Start to Renovate
articles.snippet: After paying top dollar for an apartment, most buyers among the newly wealthy see the need for more work.
articles.abstract: After paying top dollar for an apartment, most buyers among the newly wealthy see the need for more work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julia Kim rapped her spiked Gucci heels along the floor of a Midtown furniture showroom earlier this year as she approached a $30,000 custom wraparound couch that will be the centerpiece of the Manhattan co-op apartment she plans to share with her fiancé, Stephen Rushmore.

articles.headline: A Priest Methodically Reveals Ukrainian Jews’ Fate
articles.snippet: Patrick Desbois roams Ukraine’s back roads and forgotten fields to document the Nazis’ murder of 1.5 million Jews.
articles.abstract: Patrick Desbois roams Ukraine’s back roads and forgotten fields to document the Nazis’ murder of 1.5 million Jews.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 5 — His subjects were mostly children and teenagers at the time, terrified witnesses to mass slaughter. Some were forced to work at the bottom rung of the Nazi killing machine — as diggers of mass graves, cooks who fed Nazi soldiers and seamstresses who mended clothes stripped from the Jews before execution.

articles.headline: Job Growth Looks Rosier, Easing Recession Fears
articles.snippet: Job growth was much stronger this summer than the government had first estimated, making it less likely that the Fed will cut interest rates again later this month.
articles.abstract: Job growth was much stronger this summer than the government had first estimated, making it less likely that the Fed will cut interest rates again later this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: The portrait of the economy took on a strikingly different cast yesterday.

articles.headline: Wine Made the Co-op Way
articles.snippet: In a new model for California vintners, start-ups share supply and distribution but retain the independence of their individual labels.
articles.abstract: In a new model for California vintners, start-ups share supply and distribution but retain the independence of their individual labels.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — Michael Mondavi is back in the wine business — with a twist.

articles.headline: Bush Says Interrogation Methods Aren’t Torture
articles.snippet: The president championed a once-secret program to detain and interrogate high-profile terror suspects, provoking recriminations on Capitol Hill.
articles.abstract: The president championed a once-secret program to detain and interrogate high-profile terror suspects, provoking recriminations on Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 — President Bush, reacting to a Congressional uproar over the disclosure of secret Justice Department legal opinions permitting the harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects, defended the methods on Friday, declaring, “This government does not torture people.”

articles.headline: For Schools, Lottery Payoffs Fall Short of Promises
articles.snippet: Most of the billions of dollars raised by state lotteries is used simply to sustain the games, an examination by The Times has found.
articles.abstract: Most of the billions of dollars raised by state lotteries is used simply to sustain the games, an examination by The Times has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, North Carolina’s governor, Mike Easley, finally delivered on his promise to start a lottery, making his state the most recent of the 42 states and the District of Columbia to cash in on legalized gambling.
articles.byline: By Ron Stodghill and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: A Made-for-TV Boss Helps Revive ABC
articles.snippet: Meet Stephen McPherson, the latest Hollywood executive cast in the dual roles of entertainment genius and volatile bulldozer.
articles.abstract: Meet Stephen McPherson, the latest Hollywood executive cast in the dual roles of entertainment genius and volatile bulldozer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

articles.headline: Rape Epidemic Raises Trauma of Congo War
articles.snippet: Women are being systematically attacked on a scale never before seen in eastern Congo, where large regions remain lawless.
articles.abstract: Women are being systematically attacked on a scale never before seen in eastern Congo, where large regions remain lawless.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUKAVU, Congo — Denis Mukwege, a Congolese gynecologist, cannot bear to listen to the stories his patients tell him anymore.

articles.headline: Thou Shalt Not Kill, Except in a Popular Video Game at Church
articles.snippet: Ministers and pastors desperate to reach young congregants are using an unusual recruiting tool: the violent video game Halo.
articles.abstract: Ministers and pastors desperate to reach young congregants are using an unusual recruiting tool: the violent video game Halo.
articles.lead_paragraph: First the percussive sounds of sniper fire and the thrill of the kill. Then the gospel of peace.

articles.headline: Man in Citi’s Hot Seat
articles.snippet: Doubts have resurfaced about the future of Charles O. Prince III, C.E.O. of Citigroup, which has stumbled in recent months.
articles.abstract: Doubts have resurfaced about the future of Charles O. Prince III, C.E.O. of Citigroup, which has stumbled in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN late July, Charles O. Prince III began daily meetings with about 10 of Citigroup’s highest-ranking executives in his cherry-paneled library to discuss financial threats looming over the world’s largest bank. Mr. Prince had recently presided over Citigroup’s most profitable quarter since he became chief executive four years earlier, but the bank’s brain trust was worried.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Fall From the Top Lands McCain in a Scaled-Back Comfort Zone
articles.snippet: No longer swollen with overhead, a newly slimmer campaign better fits Senator John McCain’s maverick sensibility.
articles.abstract: No longer swollen with overhead, a newly slimmer campaign better fits Senator John McCain’s maverick sensibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 4 — Senator John McCain is trying to come off as one of those of-the-moment, 21st-century presidential candidates. He did Jon Stewart’s show, can use a BlackBerry. It’s important to talk to bloggers, too, Mr. McCain says, “painful as that might be.”

articles.headline: In Life of Lies, Iraqis Conceal Work for U.S.
articles.snippet: Desperate for work of any kind, Iraqis do what they must, even though affiliation with Americans makes them targets.
articles.abstract: Desperate for work of any kind, Iraqis do what they must, even though affiliation with Americans makes them targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 6 — For Hamed, a forklift driver at an American military base, life has become a series of disguises.

articles.headline: Medicare Audits Show Problems in Private Plans
articles.snippet: Medicare recipients have been victimized by private insurers that run the drug benefit program, according to a review of federal audits.
articles.abstract: Medicare recipients have been victimized by private insurers that run the drug benefit program, according to a review of federal audits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Tens of thousands of Medicare recipients have been victims of deceptive sales tactics and had claims improperly denied by private insurers that run the system’s huge new drug benefit program and offer other private insurance options encouraged by the Bush administration, a review of scores of federal audits has found.

articles.headline: A Taskmaster Who Changed Business News
articles.snippet: James Walker Michaels, who died last week at 86, was the editor of Forbes magazine for almost 40 years, in which he sharpened and refined business reporting in America.
articles.abstract: James Walker Michaels, who died last week at 86, was the editor of Forbes magazine for almost 40 years, in which he sharpened and refined business reporting in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRASCIBLE, exacting, fearless and determinedly pro-investor, James Walker Michaels, the editor of Forbes magazine for almost 40 years, died last week at 86. Because he sharpened and refined what had passed for business and financial reporting in America, he earned a place in journalistic history.

articles.headline: For Google, Advertising and Phones Go Together
articles.snippet: Google, which seeks to extend its dominance of online advertising to the mobile Internet, is expected to unveil the fruit of its secret mobile phone project later this year.
articles.abstract: Google, which seeks to extend its dominance of online advertising to the mobile Internet, is expected to unveil the fruit of its secret mobile phone project later this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 — For more than two years, a large group of engineers at Google has been working in secret on a mobile phone project. As word about their efforts has trickled out, expectations in the tech world for what has been called the Google phone, or GPhone, have risen, the way they do for Apple loyalists ahead of a speech by Steven P. Jobs.

articles.headline: Nerd Chic Arrives on TV
articles.snippet: As a new audience raised on broadband comes together, seemingly goofy little enterprises like Boing Boing could end up playing very large for their size.
articles.abstract: As a new audience raised on broadband comes together, seemingly goofy little enterprises like Boing Boing could end up playing very large for their size.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a Santa Monica television studio last Thursday, a cluster of people gathered around an intricate apparatus that Mark Frauenfelder, the founder of Boing Boing, had built.

articles.headline: Seeking Columbus’s Origins, With a Swab
articles.snippet: DNA may help solve a dispute between those who claim alternative bragging rights to Christopher Columbus.
articles.abstract: DNA may help solve a dispute between those who claim alternative bragging rights to Christopher Columbus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — When schoolchildren turn to the chapter on Christopher Columbus’s humble origins as the son of a weaver in Genoa, they are not generally told that he might instead have been born out of wedlock to a Portuguese prince. Or that he might have been a Jew whose parents converted to escape the Spanish Inquisition. Or a rebel in the medieval kingdom of Catalonia.

articles.headline: Afghans Pressed by U.S. on Plan to Spray Poppies
articles.snippet: U.S. officials have found supporters within President Hamid Karzai’s government of their push to spray herbicide on opium poppies.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials have found supporters within President Hamid Karzai’s government of their push to spray herbicide on opium poppies.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 7 — After the biggest opium harvest in Afghanistan’s history, American officials have renewed efforts to persuade the government here to begin spraying herbicide on opium poppies, and they have found some supporters within President Hamid Karzai’s administration, officials of both countries said.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Tim Golden

articles.headline: Death, Havoc and Heat Mar Chicago Race
articles.snippet: As temperatures soared, hundreds of runners in the Chicago marathon fell ill and at least one died on Sunday.
articles.abstract: As temperatures soared, hundreds of runners in the Chicago marathon fell ill and at least one died on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Oct. 7 — As temperatures soared into the upper 80s, hundreds of runners in the Chicago marathon fell ill and at least one died on Sunday, prompting officials here to halt the annual race for the first time in its 30-year history.

articles.headline: The Battle for the Consumer Online
articles.snippet: U.S. News & World Report, a master of surveys, is seeking a new role as a definitive source of information and ratings on a range of expensive consumer products.
articles.abstract: U.S. News & World Report, a master of surveys, is seeking a new role as a definitive source of information and ratings on a range of expensive consumer products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Quick, name the competitors of U.S. News & World Report. Time and Newsweek, right? Would you believe Consumer Reports?

articles.headline: When Reality TV Gets Too Real
articles.snippet: Networks and producers have increasingly pushed the boundaries of television voyeurism as they seek new ratings hits, but at times this has proved problematic.
articles.abstract: Networks and producers have increasingly pushed the boundaries of television voyeurism as they seek new ratings hits, but at times this has proved problematic.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent episode of “Intervention,” A&E’s documentary series about addiction, no one was stopping Pam, an alcoholic, from driving.

articles.headline: Immigration, Black Sheep and Swiss Rage
articles.snippet: An extreme right-wing party has turned Switzerland’s election campaign into a debate on immigration.
articles.abstract: An extreme right-wing party has turned Switzerland’s election campaign into a debate on immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCHWERZENBACH, Switzerland, Oct. 4 — The posters taped on the walls at a political rally here capture the rawness of Switzerland’s national electoral campaign: three white sheep stand on the Swiss flag as one of them kicks a single black sheep away.

articles.headline: As a Company Leaves Town, Arts Grants Follow
articles.snippet: New York’s arts community is bracing itself as one of its top donors, the tobacco giant Altria, prepares to move.
articles.abstract: New York’s arts community is bracing itself as one of its top donors, the tobacco giant Altria, prepares to move.
articles.lead_paragraph: For four decades, as New York’s arts scene flourished, the most reliable source of corporate funds for the city’s dance companies, theaters and art museums was the Philip Morris Companies, maker of the world’s most popular cigarette.

articles.headline: Don’t Open This Cookie (Disastrous Day Inside)
articles.snippet: Fortune cookies made by Wonton Food in Queens are now serving up some surprisingly downbeat advice.
articles.abstract: Fortune cookies made by Wonton Food in Queens are now serving up some surprisingly downbeat advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: The messages in fortune cookies are typically vague, banal and optimistic. But some cookies are now serving up some surprisingly downbeat advice.
